an8.51:4.5: “Sir, please let females gain the going forth from the home to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.”

an8.51:7.1: Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī thought, “The Buddha does not permit females to go forth.” Miserable and sad, weeping, with a tearful face, she bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
an8.51:8.1: Then the Buddha—when he had stayed in Kapilavatthu as long as he wished—set out for Vesālī.
an8.51:8.2: Travelling stage by stage, he arrived at Vesālī,
an8.51:8.3: where he stayed at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
an8.51:8.4: Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī had her hair cut off and put on ochre robes. Together with many Sakyan ladies she set out for Vesālī.
an8.51:8.5: Travelling stage by stage, she arrived at Vesālī and went to the Great Wood, the hall with the peaked roof.
an8.51:8.6: Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī stood crying outside the gate, her feet swollen, her body covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face.
an8.51:9.1: Venerable Ānanda saw her standing there,
an8.51:9.3: “Gotamī, why do you stand crying outside the gate, your feet swollen, your body covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face?”
an8.51:9.4: “Sir, Ānanda, it’s because the Buddha does not permit females to go forth in the teaching and practice proclaimed by the Realized One.”
an8.51:9.5: “Well then, Gotamī, wait here just a moment, while I ask the Buddha to grant the going forth for females.”
an8.51:10.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,
an8.51:10.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
an8.51:10.4: “Sir, Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī is standing crying outside the gate, her feet swollen, her body covered with dust, miserable and sad, with tearful face.
an8.51:10.5: She says that it’s because the Buddha does not permit females to go forth.
an8.51:10.6: Sir, please let females gain the going forth from the home to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.”
an8.51:10.8: Don’t advocate for females to gain the going forth from the home to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.”

an8.51:12.7: “If a woman is able to realize the fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection once she has gone forth.
an8.51:12.8: Sir, Mahāpajāpatī was very helpful to the Buddha. As his aunt, she raised him, nurtured him, and gave him her milk.
an8.51:12.9: When the Buddha’s birth-mother died, she nurtured him at her own breast.
an8.51:12.10: Sir, please let females gain the going forth from the home to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.”

an8.51:27.2: In the same way, sir, I accept these eight principles of respect as not to be transgressed for the rest of my life.”

an8.51:29.1: “Ānanda, if females had not gained the going forth from the lay life to homelessness in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One, the spiritual life would have lasted long. The true teaching would have remained for a thousand years.
an8.51:29.2: But since they have gained the going forth, now the spiritual life will not last long.
an8.51:29.3: The true teaching will remain only five hundred years.
an8.51:30.1: It’s like those families with many women and few men. They’re easy prey for bandits and thieves.
an8.51:30.2: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
an8.51:31.1: It’s like a field full of rice. Once the disease called ‘white bones’ attacks, it doesn’t last long.
an8.51:31.2: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
an8.51:32.1: It’s like a field full of sugar cane. Once the disease called ‘red rot’ attacks, it doesn’t last long.
an8.51:32.2: In the same way, the spiritual life does not last long in a teaching and training where females gain the going forth.
an8.51:33.1: As a man might build a dyke around a large lake as a precaution against the water overflowing,
an8.51:33.2: in the same way as a precaution I’ve prescribed the eight principles of respect as not to be transgressed for life.”
